liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For months, the No campaign has cited fears of legal risks arising from the wording of the proposed amendment to the constitution. Former High Court Judge Kenneth Hayne told RN's Patricia Karvelas this morning that the "overwhelming weight" among constitutional lawyers and scholars was that the wording was "wholly sound". He said a person or group taking an issue to court should not be feared. "It is simply a by-product of the fact that we live in a rule of law society," Mr Hayne said. "People can go to court to test issues. "The fact that someone wants to bring a challenge does not mean that the challenge will succeed." Listen to the full audio below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Voice wording legally 'wholly sound' says former High Court judge

featuredLink.title: Voice wording legally 'wholly sound' says former High Court judge - ABC listen

children.content: For months, the No campaign has cited fears of legal risks arising from the wording of the proposed amendment to the constitution.
Former High Court Judge Kenneth Hayne
told
RN's Patricia Karvelas
this morning that the "overwhelming weight" among constitutional lawyers and scholars was that the wording was "wholly sound".
He said a person or group taking an issue to court should not be feared.
"It is simply a by-product of the fact that we live in a rule of law society," Mr Hayne said.
"People can go to court to test issues.
"The fact that someone wants to bring a challenge does not mean that the challenge will succeed."
Listen to the full audio below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yes. All Australian citizens aged 18 and over must vote in the referendum. If you're on the electoral roll and do not vote, you will need to provide a valid reason explaining why If you don't you may face a $20 fine, courtesy of the AEC. Find out more below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is it compulsory to vote in the Voice referendum?

featuredLink.title: Is it compulsory to vote in the Voice referendum? Here's what you should know

children.content: Yes.
All Australian citizens aged 18 and over must vote in the referendum.
If you're on the electoral roll and do not vote, you will need to provide a valid reason explaining why
If you don't
you may face a $20 fine
, courtesy of the AEC.
Find out more below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jessica Warriner SA Premier Peter Malinauskas and opposition leader David Speirs have both spoken on ABC Radio Adelaide this morning ahead of Saturday's referendum. Talkback callers asked how a potential federal Voice would interact with SA's own Voice to Parliament. Mr Malinauskas, in the Yes camp, said the two are "completely separate propositions". "If there's a Yes outcome on the weekend, the state-based Voice and the federally-based Voice will be unique," he said. "That is in many respects no different to countless other organisations that the parliament and government have set up to provide on any number of decisions." Mr Speirs, a No campaigner, was also asked by callers if he were to win the next election, would the Liberals change the state Voice. "I've been very clear publicly that we would watch the state-based Voice as it unfolded and would be open to amending it or changing the way it worked, if it wasn't working effectively," he said. "We'll have to see the outcome in South Australia on Saturday evening or Sunday when those results become apparent as to whether a No vote in South Australia can be read as a lack of support for the premier's legislated state-based voice."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: South Australian premier and opposition leader debate Voice

children.content: SA Premier Peter Malinauskas (left) and Opposition Leader David Speirs (right).
(ABC News: Che Chorley)
Reporting by Jessica Warriner
SA Premier Peter Malinauskas
and
opposition leader David Speirs
have both spoken on ABC Radio Adelaide this morning ahead of Saturday's referendum.
Talkback callers asked how a potential federal Voice would interact with SA's own Voice to Parliament.
Mr Malinauskas, in the Yes camp, said the two are "completely separate propositions".
"If there's a Yes outcome on the weekend, the state-based Voice and the federally-based Voice will be unique," he said.
"That is in many respects no different to countless other organisations that the parliament and government have set up to provide on any number of decisions."
Mr Speirs, a No campaigner, was also asked by callers if he were to win the next election, would the Liberals change the state Voice.
"I've been very clear publicly that we would watch the state-based Voice as it unfolded and would be open to amending it or changing the way it worked, if it wasn't working effectively," he said.

"We'll have to see the outcome in South Australia on Saturday evening or Sunday when those results become apparent as to whether a No vote in South Australia can be read as a lack of support for the premier's legislated state-based voice."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Monash University lecturer and analyst on Israel and Middle Eastern Affairs Ran Porat has spoken with ABC News about how the unity government in Israel will work. "The practicalities of this government will be mostly around the cabinet and the additional minister that will join the government," Dr Porat says. "There is going to be five new ministers with no official titles and others will stand at the side as onlookers. "The thing is the government will be stuck with a lot of veteran politicians and veterinary IDF, Israeli army commanders, including two former chief of staff themselves. "The idea is to have people with experience in operational aspects of war with consideration or considering the implications of specific rules and also discussing what is on everybody's mind the day after, what will happen, what is the exit strategy of this war in response to Hamas's horrendous attack on Israel." He says it is a "positive step in the eyes of the Israeli public". Dr Porat says despite the unity government forming, the criticisms of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government will not go away. "It is put on ice but it does not go away," he says. "[Mr] Netanyahu did make it clear he will not put anything controversial now, which is expected, but people in Israel have not forgotten [the judicial overhaul]." " Many on the camp that objected to the judicial overhaul see [Mr] Netanyahu possibly with some truth behind him that he is responsible for this global failure. " "The divisions in Israel is understood [to be] around the Middle East as a sign of weakness. " It is something that the enemies of Israel saw fit as a sort of opportunity to attack Israel because they saw Israel as weak." Dr Porat says all the divisions have been put aside and the Israeli public is completely behind the war effort.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ran Porat explains how Israel's unity government will work

Ran Porat
has spoken with ABC News about how the unity government in Israel will work.
"The practicalities of this government will be mostly around the cabinet and the additional minister that will join the government," Dr Porat says.

"The thing is the government will be stuck with a lot of veteran politicians and veterinary IDF, Israeli army commanders, including two former chief of staff themselves.

"The idea is to have people with experience in operational aspects of war with consideration or considering the implications of specific rules and also discussing what is on everybody's mind the day after, what will happen, what is the exit strategy of this war in response to Hamas's horrendous attack on Israel."
He says it is a "positive step in the eyes of the Israeli public".

in Israel is understood [to be] around the

It is something that the enemies of Israel saw fit as a sort of opportunity to attack Israel because they saw Israel as weak."
Dr Porat says all the divisions have been put aside and the Israeli public is completely behind the war effort.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By political reporter Jake Evans Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong has confirmed a third repatriation flight for citizens in Israel is being arranged. The flight will leave early next week with further details to be released by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade within the next 24 hours. Senator Wong says the department is coordinating the flight, and anyone seeking to leave should register their interest through Smart Traveller. She said the government was considering whether further flights were needed. "I did last night agree to a third flight," she said. "My anticipation is that demand will require at least a further flight. We will look at whether any further assisted departures are required."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Penny Wong confirms third repatriation flight for Australians in Israel

children.content: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong.
(ABC News: Adam Kennedy)
By political reporter Jake Evans
Foreign Affairs Minister
Penny Wong
has confirmed a third repatriation flight for citizens in Israel is being arranged.
The flight will leave early next week with further details to be released by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade within the next 24 hours.
Senator Wong says the department is coordinating the flight, and anyone seeking to leave should register their interest through
Smart Traveller
She said the government was considering whether further flights were needed.
"I did last night agree to a third flight," she said.
"My anticipation is that demand will require at least a further flight. We will look at whether any further assisted departures are required."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Joe Biden has been meeting with Jewish community leaders in Washington, telling them the US was warning Iran to "be careful". "This attack was a campaign of pure cruelty – not just hate, but cruelty – against the Jewish people," he told the gathering at the White House. "I would argue it's the deadliest day for Jews since the Holocaust." The US president said he'd spoken again to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today, and he'd promised him more military aid. America is also bolstering its military presence in the broader region to deter other enemies of Israel from trying to widen the war. "We moved the US carrier fleet to the eastern Mediterranean and we are sending more fighter jets to that region and made it clear to the Iranians — be careful," he said. Earlier, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there was no evidence linking Iran directly to Saturday's attack. But he said security agencies would "continue to look at the intelligence stream and see if it leads us to different conclusions".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden says Hamas attack was a campaign of 'pure cruelty' against Jewish people, warns Iran to 'be careful'

children.content: Joe Biden has been meeting with Jewish community leaders in Washington, telling them the US was warning Iran to "be careful".
"This attack was a campaign of pure cruelty – not just hate, but cruelty – against the Jewish people," he told the gathering at the White House.
"I would argue it's the deadliest day for Jews since the Holocaust."

props.alt: Joe Biden speaks at a podium between to American flags. People watch him from a long desk.

children.content: Joe Biden speaks to Jewish leaders in the Indian Treaty Room at the White House.
(AP: Susan Walsh)
The US president said he'd spoken again to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today, and he'd promised him more military aid.
America is also bolstering its military presence in the broader region to deter other enemies of Israel from trying to widen the war.
"We moved the US carrier fleet to the eastern Mediterranean and we are sending more fighter jets to that region and made it clear to the Iranians — be careful," he said.
Earlier, White House national security spokesman John Kirby said there was no evidence linking Iran directly to Saturday's attack.
But he said security agencies would "continue to look at the intelligence stream and see if it leads us to different conclusions".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The future number one draft pick was on SEN WA this morning, and had a very clear message to Eagles fans — and the rest of the competition — when it comes to his preparedness to head west. "To all the Eagles fans listening, I don't know how many times I have to say this. "I'm happy to go to the Eagles and grateful to be in the position I am. I'll happily come west and wear number 9." Cousins. Naitanui. Reid? If the Eagles do trade the number one pick, it won't be because Reid is a flight risk.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Harley Reid: West Coast's number 9?

children.content: (Getty Images)
The future number one draft pick was on SEN WA this morning, and had a very clear message to Eagles fans — and the rest of the competition — when it comes to his preparedness to head west.
"To all the Eagles fans listening, I don't know how many times I have to say this.
"I'm happy to go to the Eagles and grateful to be in the position I am. I'll happily come west and wear number 9."
Cousins. Naitanui. Reid?
If the Eagles do trade the number one pick, it won't be because Reid is a flight risk.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday, Adrian Dodoro flagged that Essendon would be submitting paperwork for St Kilda's Jade Gresham within the next 24 hours. That means we should be expecting some movement today. From all reports, if the offer triggers band two compensation — which would mean St Kilda get an end-of-first-round pick — the Saints would not match. But anything less than that and they would try to get the Bombers to the trade table. At that point, there's a pretty good chance Gresham stays put. So it all hangs on the Essendon offer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will we get some Jade Gresham news today?

children.content: (Getty Images)
Yesterday, Adrian Dodoro flagged that Essendon would be submitting paperwork for St Kilda's Jade Gresham within the next 24 hours. That means we should be expecting some movement today.

From all reports, if the offer triggers band two compensation — which would mean St Kilda get an end-of-first-round pick — the Saints would not match. But anything less than that and they would try to get the Bombers to the trade table.
At that point, there's a pretty good chance Gresham stays put. So it all hangs on the Essendon offer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Is there any world in which Geelong could get Ollie Lord as part of an Esava Ratugolea trade? Could they use pick 7 in some sort of deal? Given Hawkins is on the way out, the Cats should go hard at him.

Dean, tell me there's hope. Please. - Brad. Ratugolea for Lord? Ratugolea is off-contract! Tell Geelong they're dreaming. - Wil. What are your thoughts on Geelong wanting Ollie Lord to leave Alberton as part of a trade for Esava Ratugolea with Port Adelaide rather than taking pick 24? - Adam. This is all based on reports out of Adelaide overnight that not only are Geelong saying no to pick 24 for Esava Ratugolea, they also want Ollie Lord out of Port Adelaide too. At the moment, I would call this wildly optimistic. But Geelong are no strangers to some aggressive negotiating at the trade table, and more often than not it works out well for them. I imagine Port will end up chucking a little something else to pick 24 to get the deal done. But I'd be pretty stunned if that something else was Ollie Lord.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's all this Ollie Lord talk?

children.content:
Is there any world in which Geelong could get Ollie Lord as part of an Esava Ratugolea trade? Could they use pick 7 in some sort of deal? Given Hawkins is on the way out, the Cats should go hard at him.

Dean, tell me there's hope. Please.
- Brad
Ratugolea for Lord? Ratugolea is off-contract! Tell Geelong they're dreaming.
- Wil
What are your thoughts on Geelong wanting Ollie Lord to leave Alberton as part of a trade for Esava Ratugolea with Port Adelaide rather than taking pick 24?
- Adam
This is all based on reports out of Adelaide overnight that not only are Geelong saying no to pick 24 for Esava Ratugolea, they also want Ollie Lord out of Port Adelaide too.
(Getty Images)
At the moment, I would call this wildly optimistic. But Geelong are no strangers to some aggressive negotiating at the trade table, and more often than not it works out well for them.
I imagine Port will end up chucking a little something else to pick 24 to get the deal done. But I'd be pretty stunned if that something else was Ollie Lord.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lithium miner Liontown Resources has extended an exclusive due diligence period by a week for its proposed $6.6 billion buyout by US-based Albemarle. You might remember Ablemarle has bene courting Liontown for months now and revised their offer to $3 share about a month ago. But since then Australia's richest person Gina Rinehart has been not-so-quietly buying up stock to increase her share in the company. Liontown had granted the world's biggest lithium chemical maker, Ablemarle, a four-week period to examine its books to enable it to put forward a binding offer. Albemarle's due diligence is substantially complete and it requires a short extension, Liontown said. Ms Rinehart's firm, Hancock Prospecting, has again increased its stake in Liontown to 19.9 per cent. It's enough to potentially hamper the US mining giant's takeover attempt. Albemarle needs 75 per cent support from Liontown investors in a shareholder vote to succeed with its bid. A stake of between 15 per cent and 20 per cent can often become a blocking stake depending on investor turnout on the day of the shareholder vote. Liontown had backed Albemarle's offer to shareholders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Albemarle given more time in takeover bid for Liontown

Liontown had granted the world's biggest lithium chemical maker, Ablemarle, a four-week period to examine its books to enable it to put forward a binding offer.

It's enough to potentially hamper the US mining giant's takeover attempt.

A stake of between 15 per cent and 20 per cent can often become a blocking stake depending on investor turnout on the day of the shareholder vote.
Liontown had backed Albemarle's offer to shareholders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senior business correspondent Peter Ryan, has given ABC's The World Today an update on the Senate inquiry into consulting firms, where PwC is fronting. He explained to presenter Sally Sara, former PwC Australia chief executive Luke Sayer told the inquiry he was unaware of confidentiality breaches over multinational tax avoidance that triggered a scandal earlier this year. Earlier, new CEO Kevin Burrowes named Mr Sayers and another former CEO Tom Seymour when grilled about "failures of leadership" at PwC. You can take a listen at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New PwC boss throws former CEOs Luke Sayers, Tom Seymour under Senate inquiry bus
